publicationStmt.p: Distributed by Digital Scholarship Services at Lafayette College

lg.l: Great Sṛ than Phoebus more divine,
Whose Verses far his Rays outshineLook down upon Your Quondam Foe
Oh! let me never Write again
If e'er I disoblidge You, Dean,Shou'd You compassion show.
Take those Invectives which I wrote,
When Anger made me piping hot,And give them to Your Cook;
To singe your Fowl, or save Your Paste
The next time when You have a FeastThey'll save You many a Book.
To Burn them You are not content,
I give You then my free ConsentTo sink them in the Harbour;
If not they'll serve to sett off Blocks
To Roll on Pipes, and Twist in LocksSo give them to Your Barber.
Or when that next You Physick take
I must intreat You then to makeA proper Aplication:
'Tis what I've done my self before
With Dan's Fine Thoughts and many moreWho gave me Provocation.
What cannot mighty Anger do?
It makes the Weak the strong pursue,A Goose attack a Swan:
It makes a Woman Tooth and nail
Her Husband's hands and Face AssailOr Tap him with her Fan.
Tho' some we find are more discreet,
Before the World are Wond'rous sweet,And let their Husbands hector;
But when the World's asleep they Wake
Then is the time they Chuse to speakWittness the Curtain Lecture.
Such was the Case with You I find,
All day You could conceal Your Mind,But when Sṭ Patrick's Chimes
Awak'd Your Muse (my Midnight Curse
Which I engag'd for better for Worse)You scolded with Your Rhymes.
Have done, have done I Quit the Field
To You as to My Wife I Yield,As She does wear the Breeches
So shall You wear the Lawrell Crown
Win Gold and wear it, 'tis Your OwnAnd all the Poet's Riches.S032002D
